title: Giving Feedback That Lands
shortDescription: Master techniques for delivering feedback that is heard, understood, and acted upon.
longDescription: Learn the art of delivering feedback that actually makes a difference. This comprehensive guide covers preparation, delivery techniques, and follow-up strategies to ensure your feedback is received constructively and leads to meaningful change.

levels.title: Preparing for Feedback Conversations
levels.summary: Learn how to prepare effectively for feedback that will be well-received
keyPoints: Clarify your intention before starting the conversation
Gather specific examples and data to support your feedback
Choose the right timing and setting for the conversation
Check your own emotional state before delivering feedback

items.prompt: What is the most important question to ask yourself before giving feedback?

promptI18n.zh: 在給予回饋之前，問自己最重要的問題是什麼？

options.text: How can I make them feel bad?

textI18n.zh: 我如何能讓他們感覺不好？

options.text: What is my intention and what outcome do I want?

textI18n.zh: 我的意圖是什麼，我想要什麼結果？

options.text: How quickly can I get this over with?

textI18n.zh: 我能多快完成這件事？

options.text: What will they think of me?

textI18n.zh: 他們會怎麼看我？

items.explanation: Clarifying your intention ensures your feedback is constructive and focused on improvement rather than criticism.

explanationI18n.zh: 澄清您的意圖可以確保您的回饋是建設性的，並專注於改進而不是批評。

items.prompt: When is the best time to give difficult feedback?

promptI18n.zh: 什麼時候是給予困難回饋的最佳時機？

options.text: Immediately, no matter what the circumstances

textI18n.zh: 立即，無論情況如何

options.text: In a private setting when both parties are calm and have time

textI18n.zh: 在雙方都冷靜且有時間的私人環境中

options.text: Never - avoid difficult conversations

textI18n.zh: 從不 - 避免困難的對話

options.text: In front of the whole team to make an example

textI18n.zh: 在整個團隊面前作為榜樣

items.explanation: Private settings with adequate time allow for open dialogue and reduce defensiveness, making feedback more likely to be received well.

explanationI18n.zh: 有足夠時間的私人環境允許開放對話並減少防禦心理，使回饋更有可能被很好地接受。

items.prompt: Describe a feedback conversation that went poorly. Looking back, how could better preparation have changed the outcome?

promptI18n.zh: 描述一次進展不順利的回饋對話。回顧過去，更好的準備如何能改變結果？

items.placeholder: Reflect on what was missing in the preparation...

placeholderI18n.zh: 反思準備過程中缺少了什麼...

items.guidance: Consider timing, setting, your emotional state, and whether you had clear intentions and examples.

guidanceI18n.zh: 考慮時機、環境、您的情緒狀態，以及您是否有明確的意圖和例子。

items.message: Great! You understand the importance of preparation. Let's learn techniques for delivering feedback effectively.

messageI18n.zh: 很好！您了解了準備的重要性。讓我們學習有效傳遞回饋的技巧。

items.actionHint: Ready to learn delivery techniques? Continue to the next section.

actionHintI18n.zh: 準備好學習傳遞技巧了嗎？繼續到下一部分。

levels.title: Delivering Feedback Effectively
levels.summary: Master proven techniques for delivering feedback that is heard and understood
keyPoints: Use specific, observable behaviors rather than judgments
Focus on impact rather than intent
Ask questions to ensure understanding and invite dialogue

items.prompt: Which feedback statement is most effective?

options.text: You're always late to meetings.

textI18n.zh: 你總是遲到會議。

options.text: I noticed you were late to the last three team meetings, which delayed our start time.

textI18n.zh: 我注意到你遲到了最近三次團隊會議，這延遲了我們的開始時間。

options.text: Your time management needs improvement.

textI18n.zh: 你的時間管理需要改進。

options.text: Nobody likes it when you're late.

textI18n.zh: 沒有人喜歡你遲到。

items.explanation: Specific, observable facts are actionable and less likely to trigger defensiveness than generalizations or judgments.

explanationI18n.zh: 具體的、可觀察的事實是可操作的，並且比概括或判斷更不容易引發防禦心理。

items.prompt: Why is focusing on impact more effective than focusing on intent?

promptI18n.zh: 為什麼專注於影響比專注於意圖更有效？

options.text: Intent is always positive, so it doesn't matter

textI18n.zh: 意圖總是積極的，所以它不重要

options.text: Impact is what actually affects others and the work

textI18n.zh: 影響是實際影響他人和工作的因素

options.text: Intent is impossible to know

textI18n.zh: 意圖是不可能知道的

options.text: Impact is always negative

textI18n.zh: 影響總是消極的

items.explanation: Focusing on impact helps the recipient understand the real consequences of their behavior, regardless of what they intended.

explanationI18n.zh: 專注於影響可以幫助接收者理解他們行為的真正後果，無論他們的意圖是什麼。

items.prompt: How would you deliver feedback to a colleague who consistently interrupts others in meetings? What would you say?

promptI18n.zh: 您將如何向一位在會議中經常打斷他人的同事給予回饋？您會說什麼？

placeholderI18n.zh: 在此寫下您的回饋陳述...

items.guidance: Use specific observations, focus on impact, and frame it as an invitation to improve rather than a criticism.

guidanceI18n.zh: 使用具體的觀察，專注於影響，並將其框架為改進的邀請而不是批評。

items.message: Excellent! You're mastering delivery techniques. Now let's learn about follow-up and ensuring impact.

messageI18n.zh: 太棒了！您正在掌握傳遞技巧。現在讓我們學習關於後續跟進和確保影響。

items.actionHint: Ready to learn about follow-up strategies? Continue to the next section.

actionHintI18n.zh: 準備好學習後續跟進策略了嗎？繼續到下一部分。

levels.title: Following Up and Ensuring Impact
levels.summary: Learn strategies to ensure feedback leads to meaningful change
keyPoints: Create clear action plans together after feedback
Schedule follow-up conversations to check progress
Provide support and resources for improvement

items.prompt: What is the best approach after giving feedback?

promptI18n.zh: 給予回饋後最好的方法是什麼？

options.text: Walk away and hope they figure it out

textI18n.zh: 走開並希望他們自己想明白

options.text: Create an action plan together and schedule a follow-up

textI18n.zh: 一起制定行動計劃並安排後續跟進

options.text: Give the same feedback again the next day

textI18n.zh: 第二天再次給出相同的回饋

options.text: Document it in their performance review for later

textI18n.zh: 將其記錄在績效評估中以便以後使用

items.explanation: Creating an action plan together ensures clarity and commitment, while follow-up conversations provide accountability and support.

explanationI18n.zh: 一起制定行動計劃可以確保清晰度和承諾，而後續跟進對話則提供問責和支持。

items.prompt: How should you respond when someone makes positive changes after your feedback?

promptI18n.zh: 當有人在您的回饋後做出積極改變時，您應該如何回應？

options.text: Say nothing - they're just doing what they should

textI18n.zh: 什麼也不說 - 他們只是在做應該做的事

options.text: Acknowledge and appreciate their effort and progress

textI18n.zh: 承認並感謝他們的努力和進步

options.text: Point out what they're still doing wrong

textI18n.zh: 指出他們仍然做錯的地方

options.text: Take credit for their improvement

textI18n.zh: 將他們的改進歸功於自己

items.explanation: Acknowledging positive change reinforces the behavior and builds trust, making future feedback more likely to be well-received.

explanationI18n.zh: 承認積極改變可以強化行為並建立信任，使未來的回饋更有可能被很好地接受。

items.prompt: Describe a system you would use to track feedback and follow-up across your team. How would you ensure accountability without micromanaging?

promptI18n.zh: 描述您將使用的一個系統來追蹤團隊中的回饋和後續跟進。您將如何在不微觀管理的情況下確保問責？

items.placeholder: Think about tools, processes, and communication patterns...

placeholderI18n.zh: 考慮工具、流程和溝通模式...

items.guidance: Consider regular check-ins, shared documentation, and how to balance support with autonomy.

guidanceI18n.zh: 考慮定期檢查、共享文檔，以及如何平衡支持與自主性。

items.message: Congratulations! You've mastered the complete cycle of giving feedback that lands.

messageI18n.zh: 恭喜！您已經掌握了給予有效回饋的完整週期。

items.actionHint: Ready to transform your team's feedback culture?

actionHintI18n.zh: 準備好改變您團隊的回饋文化了嗎？
